titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Robert Ward Papers, 1910-2012 and undated RL.01344
titlestmt.author: Paul Sommerfeld, Meghan Lyon

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-03-18 09:55:49 -0400.

change.item: Converted from dtd to schema, transformed with AT-import-fixer.xsl, and imported to Archivists Toolkit

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Robert Ward was a composer primarily of operas, instrumental works, and symphonic choral works. He won the 1962 Pulitzer Prize in Music for his opera, The Crucible, which remains his best-known work. Ward served as Chancellor of the North Carolina School of the Arts and as a faculty member at Columbia and Duke Universities. His papers span from his time as a student at the Eastman School of Music in the 1930s to his final years composing in 2012. They include scores, music sketches, recordings, libretto drafts, correspondence, scrapbooks, research and information files, writings and speeches by and about Ward, as well as concert programs, newspaper clippings, photographs, awards, and other materials that document his professional life and work as a composer.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials are closed to patron use. Contact Research Services for the production of listening or use copies.
The rest of the collection is open for research.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Robert Ward Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Robert Ward Papers was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1998, 2001, 2003, 2010, 2012, 2013, and 2018.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Initially processed by Don Sechler, Arístides Llaneza, Eric Hanson, and other Rubenstein Library staff.
Processed in full by Paul Sommerfeld, May 2017.
Addition 2018-0046 processed by Laurin Penland, May 2018.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Robert Ward was a composer primarily of operas, instrumental works, and symphonic choral works. Born in 1917, Ward began composing as a student. He attended the Eastman School of Music and The Juilliard School in the 1930s and early 1940s before joining the United States Army during World War II. During the war he served as a band director, and was stationed in the Pacific. Following the war, Ward taught at Juilliard and Columbia, and continued composing and conducting. His second opera, The Crucible, based on Arthur Miller's play, premiered in 1961 and became his best-known work. He won the Pulitzer Prize in Music for the opera in 1962. Ward eventually left New York and served as Chancellor of the North Carolina School of the Arts from 1967-1975. He joined Duke University as the Mary Duke Biddle Professor of Music in 1979, retiring as Professor Emeritus in 1987. He continued to live and compose in Durham, North Carolina until his death in 2013.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Robert Ward Papers have been divided into eight series: Biographical Materials, Correspondence, Operas, Instrumental Works, Vocal Works, Music Sketchbooks and Student Works, Music by Others, and Untitled Recordings. Biographical Materials consists of documents pertaining to Ward's work as a composer, including newspaper clippings, profiles, the composer's published writings and interviews, documents from the organizations with which he affiliated, events held in his honor, and certificates and awards he received. The Correspondence series primarily consists of professional communications between Robert Ward and several organizations. Ward's music has been divided into three series based on genre and arranged alphabetically by title of piece within each series: Operas, Instrumental Works, and Vocal Works. Materials for each composition may include scores, recordings, and publicity materials such as newspaper clippings, programs, and reviews. Music Sketchbooks and Student Works contains assorted untitled music sketches and sketchbooks by Ward, as well as manuscripts for some of his student works. Music by Others includes a variety of scores and recordings by other composers included in Ward's papers, the majority of which are recordings. Untitled Recordings comprises assorted media that contain no composition titles, although some recordings are labeled and dated as specific performances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Biographical Materials consists of papers pertaining to Robert Ward's professional life as composer. The series includes collected works lists and classifications compiled by both Ward and others; drafts and proofs of Ward's autobiography; biographical profiles, newspaper clippings, assorted event photographs, professional headshots of Ward, and conference and concert programs from throughout his career; details of publishing contracts and commissions for new music; and other publications on his music by Ward himself. Includes documents from the various organizations with which Ward affiliated, including: the Academy of Arts and Letters, the American Musical Theater Project, Friends of the American Musical Theatre, Durham Arts Council, Triangle Opera Theater, Opera Company of North Carolina, and cultural trips to Guatemala and Japan as part of the United States Friendship Commission. Contains materials from the celebrations for his 70th, 80th, and 90th birthdays, including programs, newspaper clippings, contracts, photographs, recordings, and music dedicated to Ward. Recordings include interviews and concert recordings celebrating Ward's music. Includes some materials from Ward's time at Duke Univeristy, such as the concert series Encounters with Music of our Time, the Summer Opera Workshop, and Winterfest. Contains papers and yearbooks from Ward's time as a student at the Eastman School of Music. Includes recordings of several interviews Ward gave throughout his career. Also includes a variety of certificates and awards received by Ward, including degrees, honorary degrees, a key to the city of Raleigh, North Carolina, State of North Carolina medal, and a golden baton from the American Symphony Orchestra League. Grouped and arranged by content type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence primarily consists of professional communications between Robert Ward and representatives from several organizations, including: churches, universities, music festivals, opera companies, and symphonies. Organizations include Galaxy Music Corporation, Duke University, North Carolina School of the Arts, Wake Forest University, Minnesota Opera Company, Ohio Light Opera, Brevard Music Center, Chicago Opera Theater, Academy of Arts and Letters, and the Nashville Symphony. The series does include some personal correspondence between Ward and his family and friends. Arranged chronologically by decade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Robert Ward and his mother

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Robert Ward and several organizations, including some churches, universities, music festivals, opera companies, and symphonies. Organizations include Duke University, North Carolina School of the Arts, Wake Forest University, Minnesota Opera Company, Ohio Light Opera, Brevard Music Center, Chicago Opera Theater, Academy of Arts and Letters, and the Nashville Symphony. Includes some personal correspondence between Ward and his family and friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Operas contains a variety of materials related to each of Robert Ward's nine completed operatic works. All of the compositions include an assortment of newspaper clippings, programs, and reviews from their performances. Clippings, programs, and reviews related to The Crucible are by far the most extensive. Almost all the operas have music sketches, libretto drafts, published libretti, piano-vocal scores, orchestral scores, conductor's scores, some individual instrumental parts, and both audio and audiovisual recordings. Media types include audiocassettes, compact discs, digital audio tapes, DVDs, reels, and VHS tapes. The scores include published versions, edited proofs—many in Ward's own hand—master sheets, printing masters, and original manuscripts. Several of the operas also include correspondence from Ward regarding revisions and performances, as well as production photographs, academic publications with musical analyses, set drawings, and stage directions. The materials for Roman Fever include a filming script. The series also includes libretto drafts for an unfinished opera entitled Debs. Recording titles are taken from the media objects themselves. Arranged alphabetically by opera title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Instrumental Works is comprised of Robert Ward's compositions for orchestra, wind ensemble, concert band, and a variety of chamber ensembles. Most of the pieces include newspaper clippings, programs, and reviews from performances, including premieres. Almost all pieces include music sketches, piano reductions, full scores, orchestral scores, conductor's scores, and complete sets of parts. Many pieces also have recordings, when noted. Media types include audiocassettes, compact discs, digital audio tapes, DVDs, and VHS tapes. The scores include published versions, edited proofs—many in Ward's own hand—master sheets, printing masters, and original manuscripts. Recording titles are taken from the media objects themselves. Arranged alphabetically by title of piece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Vocal Works is comprised of Robert Ward's pieces for solo voice, choir, spoken narrator, and chorus with larger ensemble combinations. Some works include newspaper clippings, programs, and reviews from performances. Many of the pieces include music sketches, drafts of texts, some correspondence, piano-vocal scores, full scores, orchestral scores, conductor's scores, complete sets of parts, and recordings when noted. Media types include audiocassettes, compact discs, digital audio tapes, DVDs, and VHS tapes. The scores include published versions, edited proofs—many in Ward's own hand—master sheets, printing masters, and original manuscripts. Recording titles are taken from the media objects themselves. Arranged alphabetically by title of piece.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Music Sketchbooks and Student Works contains assorted untitled music sketches and sketchbooks by Robert Ward, some of which may be related to later published works. Also includes score and parts to Ward's withdrawn work, his 1st String Quartet (not to be confused with his First String Quartet from 1966), and libretto drafts to a work entitled The Tragic Muse. Also contains various contrapuntal exercises from Ward's time at the Eastman School of Music, as well as orchestrations of works by J.S. Bach and Claude Debussy. Arranged alphabetically by folder title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Music by Others includes a variety of scores and recordings by other composers included in Robert Ward's papers. Majority of items are recordings rather than scores. Recording titles are taken from the media objects themselves. Media include audiocassettes, compact discs, digital audio tapes, LPs, reels, umatic tapes, and VHS tapes. Composers include Hugh Aitken, Samuel Barber, Belá Bartók, Leslie Bassett, William Bergsma, Leonard Bernstein, David Brackett, Margaret Brouwer, Christopher Coleman, Gaetano Donizetti, Scott Eyerely, Ernesto Ferreri, Daniel Foley, Kenneth Frazelle, Barbara Gallagher, Gordon Goodwin, Paul Hindemith, Charles Ives, Hunter Johnson, Aaron Jay Kernis, James Legg, Joseph Leniado-Chira, Scott Lindroth, Henry Mollicone, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Russell Peck, Sergei Prokofiev, Sergei Rachmaninoff, J. Mark Scearce, Jack Stamp, Stella Sung, Toru Takemitsu, Giuseppe Verdi, Richard Wargo, Donald Waxman, Ralph Vaughan Williams, and Yehudi Wyner. Arranged alphabetically by composer last name. Several recordings without a listed composer are arranged alphbetically my recording title at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains assorted media that contain no composition titles. Recording titles are taken from the media objects themselves. Some recordings are labeled and dated as specific performances. Includes audiocassettes, compact discs, digital audio tapes, reels, and VHS tapes. Listed alphabetically by recording title; physically sorted by format.
